name: 1579_B. Shifting Sort
description:
The new generation external memory contains an array of integers a[1 … n] = [a_1, a_2, …, a_n].

This type of memory does not support changing the value of an arbitrary element. Instead, it allows you to cut out any segment of the given array, cyclically shift (rotate) it by any offset and insert it back into the same place.

Technically, each cyclic shift consists of two consecutive actions: 

  1. You may select arbitrary indices l and r (1 ≤ l < r ≤ n) as the boundaries of the segment. 
  2. Then you replace the segment a[l … r] with it's cyclic shift to the left by an arbitrary offset d. The concept of a cyclic shift can be also explained by following relations: the sequence [1, 4, 1, 3] is a cyclic shift of the sequence [3, 1, 4, 1] to the left by the offset 1 and the sequence [4, 1, 3, 1] is a cyclic shift of the sequence [3, 1, 4, 1] to the left by the offset 2. 



For example, if a = [1, \color{blue}{3, 2, 8}, 5], then choosing l = 2, r = 4 and d = 2 yields a segment a[2 … 4] = [3, 2, 8]. This segment is then shifted by the offset d = 2 to the left, and you get a segment [8, 3, 2] which then takes the place of of the original elements of the segment. In the end you get a = [1, \color{blue}{8, 3, 2}, 5].

Sort the given array a using no more than n cyclic shifts of any of its segments. Note that you don't need to minimize the number of cyclic shifts. Any method that requires n or less cyclic shifts will be accepted.

Input

The first line contains an integer t (1 ≤ t ≤ 1000) — the number of test cases.

The next 2t lines contain the descriptions of the test cases. 

The first line of each test case description contains an integer n (2 ≤ n ≤ 50) — the length of the array. The second line consists of space-separated elements of the array a_i (-10^9 ≤ a_i ≤ 10^9). Elements of array a may repeat and don't have to be unique.

Output

Print t answers to all input test cases. 

The first line of the answer of each test case should contain an integer k (0 ≤ k ≤ n) — the number of actions to sort the array. The next k lines should contain descriptions of the actions formatted as "l r d" (without quotes) where l and r (1 ≤ l < r ≤ n) are the boundaries of the segment being shifted, while d (1 ≤ d ≤ r - l) is the offset value. Please remember that only the cyclic shifts to the left are considered so the chosen segment will be shifted by the offset d to the to the left.

Note that you are not required to find the minimum number of cyclic shifts needed for sorting. Any sorting method where the number of shifts does not exceed n will be accepted.

If the given array a is already sorted, one of the possible answers is k = 0 and an empty sequence of cyclic shifts.

If there are several possible answers, you may print any of them.

Example

Input


4
2
2 1
3
1 2 1
4
2 4 1 3
5
2 5 1 4 3


Output


1
1 2 1
1
1 3 2
3
2 4 1
2 3 1
1 3 2
4
2 4 2
1 5 3
1 2 1
1 3 1

Note

Explanation of the fourth data set in the example: 

  1. The segment a[2 … 4] is selected and is shifted to the left by 2: [2, \color{blue}{5, 1, 4}, 3] \longrightarrow [2, \color{blue}{4, 5, 1}, 3] 
  2. The segment a[1 … 5] is then selected and is shifted to the left by 3: [\color{blue}{2, 4, 5, 1, 3}] \longrightarrow [\color{blue}{1, 3, 2, 4, 5}] 
  3. After that the segment a[1 … 2] is selected and is shifted to the left by 1: [\color{blue}{1, 3}, 2, 4, 5] \longrightarrow [\color{blue}{3, 1}, 2, 4, 5] 
  4. And in the end the segment a[1 … 3] is selected and is shifted to the left by 1: [\color{blue}{3, 1, 2}, 4, 5] \longrightarrow [\color{blue}{1, 2, 3}, 4, 5]

This type of memory does not support changing the value of an arbitrary element. Instead, it allows you to cut out any segment of the given array, cyclically shift (rotate) it by any offset and insert it back into the same place.

Technically, each cyclic shift consists of two consecutive actions:

  2. After selecting these indices, you then replace the segment a[l … r] with it's cyclic shift to the left by an arbitrary offset d. The concept of a cyclic shift can be also explained by following relations: the sequence [1, 4, 1, 3] is a cyclic shift of the sequence [3, 1, 4, 1] to the left by the offset 1 and the sequence [4, 1, 3, 1] is a cyclic shift of the sequence [3, 1, 4, 1] to the left by the offset 2.

In the end you get a = [1, \color{blue}{8, 3, 2}, 5].

Sort the given array a using no more than n cyclic shifts of any of its segments. Note that you don't need to minimize the number of cyclic shifts. Any method that requires n or less cyclic shifts will be accepted.

Input

The next k lines should contain descriptions of the actions formatted as "l r d" (without quotes) where l and r (1 ≤ l < r ≤ n) are the boundaries of the segment being shifted, while d (1 ≤ d ≤ r - l) is the offset value. Please remember that only the cyclic shifts to the left are considered so the chosen segment will be shifted by the offset d to the to the left.

Note that you are not required to find the minimum number of cyclic shifts needed for sorting. Any sorting method where the number of shifts does not exceed n will be accepted.

If the given array a is already sorted, one of the possible answers is k = 0 and an empty sequence of cyclic shifts.

If there are several possible answers, you may print any of them.

Example

4
2
2 1
3
1 2 1
4
2 4 1 3
5
2 5 1 4 3


Output

1
1 3 2
3
2 4 1
2 3 1
1 3 2
4
2 4 2
1 5 3
1 2 1
1 3 1

Note

Explanation of the fourth data set in the example: 

  1. The segment a[2 … 4] is selected and is shifted to the left by 2: [2, \color{blue}{5, 1, 4}, 3] \longrightarrow [2, \color{blue}{4, 5, 1}, 3] 
  2. The segment a[1 … 5] is then selected and is shifted to the left by 3: [\color{blue}{2, 4, 5, 1, 3}] \longrightarrow [\color{blue}{1, 3, 2, 4, 5}] 
  3. After that the segment a[1 … 2] is selected and is shifted to the left by 1: [\color{blue}{1, 3}, 2, 4, 5] \longrightarrow [\color{blue}{3, 1}, 2, 4, 5] 
  4. And in the end the segment a[1 … 3] is selected and is shifted to the left by 1: [\color{blue}{3, 1, 2}, 4, 5] \longrightarrow [\color{blue}{1, 2, 3}, 4, 5]

completions:
from typing import List
## main.py

from typing import List, Tuple

def sort_with_cyclic_shifts(t: int, test_cases: List[Tuple[int, List[int]]]) -> List[Tuple[int, List[Tuple[int, int, int]]]]:
    """Sorts arrays using cyclic shifts.

    Args:
        t: Number of test cases.
        test_cases: A list of tuples, each containing an integer n and a list of integers representing the array.

    Returns:
        A list of tuples, each containing an integer k and a list of tuples representing the actions.
    """
    results = []

    for n, array in test_cases:
        actions = []
        
        # Check if the array is already sorted
        if array == sorted(array):
            results.append((0, actions))
            continue

        # Perform cyclic shifts to sort the array
        for i in range(n - 1):
            min_index = i
            for j in range(i + 1, n):
                if array[j] < array[min_index]:
                    min_index = j
            
            if min_index != i:
                # Perform a cyclic shift
                l = i + 1
                r = min_index + 1
                d = r - l
                actions.append((l, r, d))
                
                # Perform the cyclic shift on the array
                segment = array[l-1:r]
                array[l-1:r] = segment[d:] + segment[:d]

        results.append((len(actions), actions))

    return results

# Input interface
def main():
    t = int(input())
    test_cases = []
    for _ in range(t):
        n = int(input())
        array = list(map(int, input().split()))
        test_cases.append((n, array))

    # Call the function
    results = sort_with_cyclic_shifts(t, test_cases)

    # Output interface
    for result in results:
        k, actions = result
        print(k)
        for action in actions:
            print(*action)

if __name__ == "__main__":
    main()
from typing import List
## main.py

from typing import List, Tuple

def sort_with_cyclic_shifts(t: int, test_cases: List[Tuple[int, List[int]]]) -> List[Tuple[int, List[Tuple[int, int, int]]]]:
    """Sorts arrays using cyclic shifts and returns the number of shifts and their details.

    Args:
        t: Number of test cases.
        test_cases: A list of tuples, each containing an integer n and a list of integers representing the array.

    Returns:
        A list of tuples, each containing the number of shifts and a list of shift details (l, r, d).
    """
    results = []

    for n, a in test_cases:
        actions = []
        sorted_a = sorted(a)
        
        if a == sorted_a:
            results.append((0, actions))
            continue
        
        # Perform cyclic shifts to sort the array
        for i in range(n):
            if a[i] != sorted_a[i]:
                # Find the segment to shift
                l = i + 1
                r = n
                d = r - l
                
                # Perform the cyclic shift
                segment = a[l-1:r]
                shifted_segment = segment[d:] + segment[:d]
                a[l-1:r] = shifted_segment
                
                actions.append((l, r, d))
                
                # Check if sorted
                if a == sorted_a:
                    break
        
        results.append((len(actions), actions))
    
    return results

# Input interface
def main():
    t = int(input())
    test_cases = []
    for _ in range(t):
        n = int(input())
        a = list(map(int, input().split()))
        test_cases.append((n, a))

    # Call the function
    results = sort_with_cyclic_shifts(t, test_cases)

    # Output interface
    for result in results:
        k, actions = result
        print(k)
        for action in actions:
            print(f"{action[0]} {action[1]} {action[2]}")

if __name__ == "__main__":
    main()
from typing import List
## main.py

import typing

def sort_with_cyclic_shifts(
    t: int, 
    test_cases: typing.List[typing.Tuple[int, typing.List[int]]]
) -> typing.List[typing.Tuple[int, typing.List[typing.Tuple[int, int, int]]]]:
    """Sort arrays using cyclic shifts.

    Args:
        t: Number of test cases.
        test_cases: A list of tuples, each containing an integer n and a list of integers representing the array.

    Returns:
        A list of tuples, each containing an integer k and a list of tuples (l, r, d) representing the shifts.
    """
    results = []

    for n, array in test_cases:
        actions = []
        if array != sorted(array):
            # A simple strategy to sort the array using cyclic shifts
            # This is not necessarily optimal but satisfies the problem constraints
            for i in range(n - 1):
                min_index = i
                for j in range(i + 1, n):
                    if array[j] < array[min_index]:
                        min_index = j
                if min_index != i:
                    # Perform a cyclic shift to bring the minimum element to the correct position
                    l = i + 1
                    r = min_index + 1
                    d = r - l
                    actions.append((l, r, d))
                    # Perform the cyclic shift
                    array = array[:l-1] + array[l-1:r][d:] + array[l-1:r][:d] + array[r:]
        
        results.append((len(actions), actions))
    
    return results

def main():
    """Main function to handle input and output."""
    t = int(input())
    test_cases = []
    for _ in range(t):
        n = int(input())
        array = list(map(int, input().split()))
        test_cases.append((n, array))
    
    results = sort_with_cyclic_shifts(t, test_cases)
    for k, actions in results:
        print(k)
        for l, r, d in actions:
            print(l, r, d)

if __name__ == "__main__":
    main()
from typing import List
## main.py

import typing

def sort_with_cyclic_shifts(
    t: int, 
    test_cases: typing.List[typing.Tuple[int, typing.List[int]]]
) -> typing.List[typing.Tuple[int, typing.List[typing.Tuple[int, int, int]]]]:
    """Sorts arrays using cyclic shifts.

    Args:
        t: Number of test cases.
        test_cases: A list of tuples, each containing the length of the array and the array itself.

    Returns:
        A list of tuples, each containing the number of shifts and a list of shift operations.
    """
    results = []

    for n, array in test_cases:
        if array == sorted(array):
            # If the array is already sorted, no shifts are needed.
            results.append((0, []))
            continue

        actions = []
        # A simple strategy to sort the array using cyclic shifts
        # This is not necessarily optimal but ensures the number of shifts does not exceed n
        for i in range(n - 1):
            min_index = i
            for j in range(i + 1, n):
                if array[j] < array[min_index]:
                    min_index = j
            if min_index != i:
                # Perform a cyclic shift to bring the minimum element to the correct position
                # Shift the segment [i, min_index] to the left by 1
                actions.append((i + 1, min_index + 1, 1))
                # Perform the cyclic shift
                array[i:min_index + 1] = array[i + 1:min_index + 1] + [array[i]]

        results.append((len(actions), actions))

    return results

# Input interface
def main():
    t = int(input())
    test_cases = []
    for _ in range(t):
        n = int(input())
        array = list(map(int, input().split()))
        test_cases.append((n, array))

    # Output interface
    results = sort_with_cyclic_shifts(t, test_cases)
    for k, actions in results:
        print(k)
        for l, r, d in actions:
            print(l, r, d)

if __name__ == "__main__":
    main()
from typing import List
## main.py

from typing import List, Tuple

def sort_with_cyclic_shifts(t: int, test_cases: List[Tuple[int, List[int]]]) -> List[Tuple[int, List[Tuple[int, int, int]]]]:
    """Sorts arrays using cyclic shifts.

    Args:
        t: Number of test cases.
        test_cases: A list of tuples, each containing an integer n and a list of integers representing the array.

    Returns:
        A list of tuples, each containing an integer k and a list of actions. Each action is a tuple (l, r, d).
    """
    results = []

    for n, array in test_cases:
        actions = []
        if array == sorted(array):
            results.append((0, actions))
            continue

        # Implement a simple strategy to sort the array using cyclic shifts
        for i in range(n - 1):
            min_index = i
            for j in range(i + 1, n):
                if array[j] < array[min_index]:
                    min_index = j

            if min_index != i:
                # Perform a cyclic shift to bring the minimum element to the correct position
                l = i + 1
                r = min_index + 1
                d = r - l
                array[l-1:r] = array[l-1+d:r] + array[l-1:l-1+d]
                actions.append((l, r, d))

        results.append((len(actions), actions))

    return results

# Input interface
def main():
    import sys
    input = sys.stdin.read
    data = input().split()
    
    t = int(data[0])
    index = 1
    test_cases = []
    
    for _ in range(t):
        n = int(data[index])
        array = list(map(int, data[index+1:index+1+n]))
        test_cases.append((n, array))
        index += n + 1
    
    # Call the function and get the result
    results = sort_with_cyclic_shifts(t, test_cases)
    
    # Output interface
    for result in results:
        k, actions = result
        print(k)
        for action in actions:
            print(f"{action[0]} {action[1]} {action[2]}")

if __name__ == "__main__":
    main()
from typing import List
## main.py

from typing import List, Tuple

def sort_with_cyclic_shifts(t: int, test_cases: List[Tuple[int, List[int]]]) -> List[Tuple[int, List[Tuple[int, int, int]]]]:
    """Sorts arrays using cyclic shifts within the constraints of n operations.

    Args:
        t: Number of test cases.
        test_cases: A list of tuples, each containing the length of the array and the array itself.

    Returns:
        A list of tuples, each containing the number of operations and the details of each operation.
    """
    results = []

    for n, array in test_cases:
        operations = []
        
        # Check if the array is already sorted
        if array == sorted(array):
            results.append((0, operations))
            continue
        
        # Perform cyclic shifts to sort the array
        # This is a simple strategy that may not be optimal but satisfies the problem constraints
        for i in range(n - 1):
            if array[i] > array[i + 1]:
                # Find the segment to shift
                l = i + 1
                r = n
                d = 1
                
                # Perform the cyclic shift
                segment = array[l-1:r]
                shifted_segment = segment[d:] + segment[:d]
                array[l-1:r] = shifted_segment
                
                # Record the operation
                operations.append((l, r, d))
        
        # Append the result for the current test case
        results.append((len(operations), operations))
    
    return results

# Input interface
def main():
    t = int(input())
    test_cases = []
    for _ in range(t):
        n = int(input())
        array = list(map(int, input().split()))
        test_cases.append((n, array))

    # Call the function and get the result
    results = sort_with_cyclic_shifts(t, test_cases)

    # Output interface
    for result in results:
        k, actions = result
        print(k)
        for action in actions:
            print(' '.join(map(str, action)))

if __name__ == "__main__":
    main()
from typing import List
## main.py

import typing

def cyclic_shift_sort(t: int, test_cases: typing.List[typing.Tuple[int, typing.List[int]]]) -> typing.List[typing.Tuple[int, typing.List[typing.Tuple[int, int, int]]]]:
    results = []
    
    for n, array in test_cases:
        if array == sorted(array):
            results.append((0, []))
            continue
        
        actions = []
        for i in range(n):
            min_index = i + min(range(n - i), key=array[i:].__getitem__)
            if min_index != i:
                # Perform a cyclic shift
                l = i + 1
                r = min_index + 1
                d = r - l
                array[i:r] = array[i+d:r] + array[i:i+d]
                actions.append((l, r, d))
        
        results.append((len(actions), actions))
    
    return results

def main():
    t = int(input())
    test_cases = []
    for _ in range(t):
        n = int(input())
        array = list(map(int, input().split()))
        test_cases.append((n, array))
    
    results = cyclic_shift_sort(t, test_cases)
    for result in results:
        k, actions = result
        print(k)
        for action in actions:
            print(' '.join(map(str, action)))

if __name__ == "__main__":
    main()
from typing import List
## main.py

from typing import List, Tuple

def sort_with_cyclic_shifts(t: int, test_cases: List[Tuple[int, List[int]]]) -> List[Tuple[int, List[Tuple[int, int, int]]]]:
    """Sorts arrays using cyclic shifts and returns the number of actions and their descriptions.

    Args:
        t (int): Number of test cases.
        test_cases (List[Tuple[int, List[int]]]): List of test cases, each containing the length of the array and the array itself.

    Returns:
        List[Tuple[int, List[Tuple[int, int, int]]]]: List of results for each test case, each containing the number of actions and the actions themselves.
    """
    results = []

    for n, a in test_cases:
        actions = []
        sorted_a = sorted(a)

        if a == sorted_a:
            results.append((0, actions))
            continue

        # Implement a simple strategy to sort the array using cyclic shifts
        for i in range(n - 1):
            if a[i] > a[i + 1]:
                # Find the segment to shift
                l = i + 1
                r = n
                d = 1
                # Perform the cyclic shift
                segment = a[l - 1:r]
                shifted_segment = segment[d:] + segment[:d]
                a[l - 1:r] = shifted_segment
                actions.append((l, r, d))

                # Check if sorted
                if a == sorted_a:
                    break

        results.append((len(actions), actions))

    return results

# Input interface
t = int(input())
test_cases = []
for _ in range(t):
    n = int(input())
    a = list(map(int, input().split()))
    test_cases.append((n, a))

# Call the function
results = sort_with_cyclic_shifts(t, test_cases)

# Output interface
for result in results:
    k, actions = result
    print(k)
    for action in actions:
        print(' '.join(map(str, action)))
from typing import List
## main.py

from typing import List, Tuple

def sort_with_cyclic_shifts(t: int, test_cases: List[Tuple[int, List[int]]]) -> List[Tuple[int, List[Tuple[int, int, int]]]]:
    """Sorts arrays using cyclic shifts.

    Args:
        t: Number of test cases.
        test_cases: A list of tuples, each containing an integer n and a list of integers representing the array.

    Returns:
        A list of tuples, each containing an integer k and a list of tuples representing the cyclic shift operations.
    """
    results = []

    for n, a in test_cases:
        if a == sorted(a):
            results.append((0, []))
            continue

        actions = []
        sorted_a = sorted(a)

        # Simple strategy to sort using cyclic shifts
        for i in range(n):
            if a[i] != sorted_a[i]:
                # Find the segment to shift
                l = i + 1
                r = a.index(sorted_a[i], i) + 1
                d = r - l

                # Perform the cyclic shift
                segment = a[l-1:r]
                shifted_segment = segment[d:] + segment[:d]
                a[l-1:r] = shifted_segment

                # Record the action
                actions.append((l, r, d))

        results.append((len(actions), actions))

    return results

# Input interface
def main():
    t = int(input())
    test_cases = []
    for _ in range(t):
        n = int(input())
        a = list(map(int, input().split()))
        test_cases.append((n, a))

    # Call the function
    results = sort_with_cyclic_shifts(t, test_cases)

    # Output interface
    for result in results:
        k, actions = result
        print(k)
        for action in actions:
            print(f"{action[0]} {action[1]} {action[2]}")

if __name__ == "__main__":
    main()

from typing import List, Tuple

def sort_with_cyclic_shifts(t: int, test_cases: List[Tuple[int, List[int]]]) -> List[Tuple[int, List[Tuple[int, int, int]]]]:
    """Sorts arrays using cyclic shifts.

    Args:
        t: Number of test cases.
        test_cases: A list of tuples, each containing the length of the array and the array itself.

    Returns:
        A list of tuples, each containing the number of shifts and the details of each shift.
    """
    results = []

    for n, a in test_cases:
        actions = []
        if a == sorted(a):
            results.append((0, actions))
            continue

        # Implement a simple strategy to sort the array using cyclic shifts
        # This is a naive approach and may not be optimal, but it satisfies the problem constraints
        for i in range(n - 1):
            if a[i] > a[i + 1]:
                # Find the segment to shift
                l = i + 1
                r = n
                d = 1
                # Perform the cyclic shift
                a[l-1:r] = a[l-1+d:r] + a[l-1:l-1+d]
                actions.append((l, r, d))
                if a == sorted(a):
                    break

        results.append((len(actions), actions))

    return results

# Input interface
def main():
    t = int(input())
    test_cases = []
    for _ in range(t):
        n = int(input())
        a = list(map(int, input().split()))
        test_cases.append((n, a))

    # Call the function
    results = sort_with_cyclic_shifts(t, test_cases)

    # Output interface
    for result in results:
        k, actions = result
        print(k)
        for action in actions:
            print(f"{action[0]} {action[1]} {action[2]}")

if __name__ == "__main__":
    main()

Please read and understand the following inteperation before coding
# [core concept]
    'cyclic shift'
    Explanation: A cyclic shift involves rotating a segment of an array to the left by a specified offset. This operation allows rearranging elements within a segment without changing the overall length of the array.

    'sort the array'
    Explanation: The task is to rearrange the elements of the array in non-decreasing order using cyclic shifts.

# [phrase showing quantity relationship]
    'no more than n'
    Explanation: The number of cyclic shifts used to sort the array should not exceed the length of the array, n. This means you can use up to n shifts to achieve the sorted order.

# [degree adverb]
    No degree adverb

# [code logic]
1. For each test case, read the integer n and the array a.
2. Check if the array is already sorted. If it is, output k = 0 and an empty sequence of actions.
3. If not sorted, iterate over the array and identify segments that can be cyclically shifted to move elements into their correct positions.
4. For each identified segment, perform a cyclic shift by choosing appropriate l, r, and d values.
5. Keep track of the number of shifts performed and ensure it does not exceed n.
6. Output the number of shifts k and the details of each shift in the format "l r d".

# [edge case]
    Test case with already sorted array:
    Input: [1, 2, 3, 4, 5]
    Output: 0
    Explanation: The array is already sorted, so no shifts are needed.

    Test case with all elements equal:
    Input: [3, 3, 3, 3]
    Output: 0
    Explanation: All elements are equal, so the array is trivially sorted.

    Test case with minimum size:
    Input: [2, 1]
    Output: 1
    Explanation: A single shift is needed to sort the array.

# [extra code for edge case]
    We do not need extra code to handle the edge cases. The original logic of checking if the array is already sorted and performing shifts as needed will naturally handle these cases.

# [phrase showing quantity relationship]

    Explanation: The number of cyclic shifts performed should not exceed the length of the array, n. This constraint ensures that the solution is efficient and adheres to the problem's requirements.

    No degree adverb

# [code logic]
1. For each test case, read the integer n and the array a.
2. Check if the array is already sorted. If it is, output k = 0 and an empty sequence of shifts.

4. Use list slicing to perform the cyclic shifts:
   - Select indices l and r for the segment.
   - Determine the offset d for the left shift.
   - Perform the cyclic shift and update the array.
5. Record each shift as "l r d" and ensure the total number of shifts does not exceed n.
6. Output the number of shifts k and the sequence of shifts for each test case.

    Test case 1: [1, 1, 1, 1] = 0
    Explanation: The array is already sorted, so no shifts are needed.

Please read and understand the following inteperation before coding
# [core concept]
    'cyclic shift'
    Explanation: A cyclic shift involves rotating a segment of the array to the left by a specified offset. This operation allows rearranging elements within a segment without changing the overall size of the array.

    'sort the array'
    Explanation: The goal is to rearrange the elements of the array in non-decreasing order using cyclic shifts.

# [phrase showing quantity relationship]
    'no more than n'
    Explanation: The number of cyclic shifts used to sort the array should not exceed the length of the array, n. This means we can use up to n shifts to achieve the sorted order.

# [degree adverb]
    No degree adverb

# [code logic]
1. For each test case, read the length of the array and the array elements.
2. Check if the array is already sorted. If it is, output k = 0 and an empty sequence of shifts.
3. If not sorted, identify segments that can be cyclically shifted to move elements closer to their correct positions.
4. Perform cyclic shifts on identified segments, ensuring that the number of shifts does not exceed n.
5. Output the number of shifts performed and the details of each shift (l, r, d).

# [edge case]
    Test case 1: [1, 1, 1, 1] = 0
    Explanation: The array is already sorted, so no shifts are needed.

    Test case 2: [5, 4, 3, 2, 1] = 5
    Explanation: The array is in reverse order. We can perform a series of shifts to sort it in ascending order.

    Test case 3: [1, 3, 2] = 1
    Explanation: A single shift of segment [2, 3] by offset 1 will sort the array.

# [extra code for edge case]
    We do not need extra code to handle the edge cases. The original logic of checking if the array is already sorted and performing necessary shifts will handle these cases effectively.
examples:
Input

The first line contains an integer t (1 ≤ t ≤ 1000) — the number of test cases.

The next 2t lines contain the descriptions of the test cases. 

The first line of each test case description contains an integer n (2 ≤ n ≤ 50) — the length of the array. The second line consists of space-separated elements of the array a_i (-10^9 ≤ a_i ≤ 10^9). Elements of array a may repeat and don't have to be unique.

Output

Print t answers to all input test cases. 

The first line of the answer of each test case should contain an integer k (0 ≤ k ≤ n) — the number of actions to sort the array. The next k lines should contain descriptions of the actions formatted as "l r d" (without quotes) where l and r (1 ≤ l < r ≤ n) are the boundaries of the segment being shifted, while d (1 ≤ d ≤ r - l) is the offset value. Please remember that only the cyclic shifts to the left are considered so the chosen segment will be shifted by the offset d to the to the left.

Note that you are not required to find the minimum number of cyclic shifts needed for sorting. Any sorting method where the number of shifts does not exceed n will be accepted.

If the given array a is already sorted, one of the possible answers is k = 0 and an empty sequence of cyclic shifts.

If there are several possible answers, you may print any of them.

Example

Input


4
2
2 1
3
1 2 1
4
2 4 1 3
5
2 5 1 4 3


Output


1
1 2 1
1
1 3 2
3
2 4 1
2 3 1
1 3 2
4
2 4 2
1 5 3
1 2 1
1 3 1

Note

Explanation of the fourth data set in the example: 

  1. The segment a[2 … 4] is selected and is shifted to the left by 2: [2, \color{blue}{5, 1, 4}, 3] \longrightarrow [2, \color{blue}{4, 5, 1}, 3] 
  2. The segment a[1 … 5] is then selected and is shifted to the left by 3: [\color{blue}{2, 4, 5, 1, 3}] \longrightarrow [\color{blue}{1, 3, 2, 4, 5}] 
  3. After that the segment a[1 … 2] is selected and is shifted to the left by 1: [\color{blue}{1, 3}, 2, 4, 5] \longrightarrow [\color{blue}{3, 1}, 2, 4, 5] 
  4. And in the end the segment a[1 … 3] is selected and is shifted to the left by 1: [\color{blue}{3, 1, 2}, 4, 5] \longrightarrow [\color{blue}{1, 2, 3}, 4, 5]
